title: Louis Theroux leaves BBC Studios to start own production company after 21 years
text:
Louis has left BBC Studios to create his own company (Picture: Eleanor Bentall/Corbis via Getty Images)

Louis Theroux has ended his long-running connection with BBC Studios in a bid to start his own production company.

The documentary film maker and cult icon has been creating shows with the BBC for 21 years, with controversial and eye-opening films including intimate conversations with Jimmy Saville, the Westboro Baptist Church and recovering paedophiles.

He is now set up Mindhouse Productions, owning 40% of the company in a split with former BBC Studios producer Arron Fellows (40%) and his wife, TV director Nancy Strang (20%), Deadline revealed.

The company ends a 21-year relationship with BBC Studios, who first launched Theroux’s documentary projects with the launch of his Weird Weekends series back in 1998.

While they might not working directly with each other, the BBC said that they may continue to release his projects in the future.

‘Louis and the BBC have a strong and long-standing relationship,’ a BBC spokesperson said.

‘We look forward to continuing to work together and already have exciting projects in development for next year.’

It is not yet known what Louis is planning to produce with his new company (Picture: Daniel Zuchnik/WireImage)

It is not yet known what projects Theroux plans to create with the company, or if they could be released on the BBC, but he had teased that he’ll take a step off screen.

‘We will make shows that are similar to the sorts of things I’ve done in the past but not necessarily with me in it — first-person docs that go to extremes and also stories without me that cover similar terrain,’ he told Deadline in August.

However, it’s believed that both Amazon and Netflix are potentially interested in the filmmaker’s work, and could result on another BBC star defecting to streaming services.

Among the talent that’s ‘defected’ over the past few years includes The Grand Tour’s Jeremy Clarkson, Richard Hammond and James May, who set up a rival car show for their former home of BBC’s Top Gear on Amazon Prime.

It was also rumoured that the BBC was angry that Netflix ‘stole’ nature documentary star David Attenborough from them for their series Our Planet.
